text: So now that we got this solid foundation about building AI workflows, we're ready to finally start building AI agents and also agentic systems. Though, as I already mentioned in the previous section, you could already call some of the workflows we built there agentic systems because some people would call each step we had in there an agent, since it was a task fulfilled with help of an LLM. But we'll get back to this in this section. Because in this section here, we'll explore in depth how to build agents. And with that, I also mean fully autonomous agents. Therefore, we'll take a look at how large language models do and do not use tools, so how we can build agents by exposing tools to large language models. We'll explore how we can build pretty generic universal agents and how we can build more specialized agents and which approach might be better in certain situations. We'll learn how we can connect multiple agents and build an agentic system, and we'll also dive into memory management. And with that, I don't mean the memory of your computer, but instead short and long-term memory that can be made available to agents to make sure, uh, that they're able to remember things. Again, plenty of things to cover. Let's dive in.
